projects.elevator_pitch: An immersive system merging in-game & after-game experiences with real stories from elderly interviews, fostering intergenerational connections.
projects.description:
Silver Valley is a transformative system comprising an in-game experience and an after-game alternate reality game (ARG) experience. The primary objective of this project is to rebuild the connections between the older and younger generations, addressing the disconnection that often arises in our rapidly advancing technological landscape.

The motivation for undertaking this project stemmed from a realization that modern technology has largely overlooked the unique needs and perspectives of the elderly. I was compelled to contribute to changing this situation by designing an experience that would facilitate intergenerational communication and understanding.

In the immersive in-game experience of Silver Valley, players are transported to a magical world where they assume the roles of animal characters, each representing distinct personalities and perspectives. The project revolves around the collection of real stories through interviews with silver hair individuals, which become the foundation for the in-game content. These authentic experiences and personal histories serve as a catalyst for creating a captivating storytelling environment that resonates with players Through engaging gameplay and captivating storytelling, players are invited to explore the lives and stories of these characters, fostering empathy and connection.

However, the experience extends beyond the confines of the game. The after-game ARG experience plays a vital role in amplifying the impact of Silver Valley. It encourages players to share real stories of the elderly within their own families and communities, effectively bridging the virtual and real worlds to foster dialogue, reflection, and the celebration of diverse narratives.
projects.background:
My motivation for embarking on this project stems from a personal experience that highlighted the glaring disconnect between the rapid advancements in technology and the needs of the elderly. As a game designer, I believe that the young have the ability to design and shape the world they want to live in. However, I noticed a prevailing trend where the design of modern technology overlooks the unique requirements and perspectives of the silver hair group, leading to a significant gap between the young and the silver hair group.

When I set out to find a smart device suitable for my grandparents, I was disheartened to discover the limited options available. It became evident that the design of modern technology largely neglects the aging population, contributing to their exclusion from the digital world. This realization sparked a deep sense of sadness and a strong desire to contribute to change this situation.

Driven by my passion for inclusive design and my background in game design, I saw an opportunity to leverage the power of games to bridge the generational gap. I wanted to create a project that not only entertained but also fostered understanding and rebuilt connections between the young and the silver hair group.

I decided to embark on a thesis project that would go beyond entertainment and explore how games could address real-world challenges, specifically the disconnection between the younger and older generations. I aimed to challenge the prevailing notion that they are technologically disadvantaged and instead highlight their unique wisdom and experiences.

Throughout my research, I delved into various sources, including academic papers such as "Effects of Aging on Organ System Physiology and Drug Disposition" published on ScienceDirect, which discussed the physiological changes associated with aging and their impact on drug metabolism and stress coping mechanisms. Additionally, I explored research by Don Norman, as featured in "I Wrote the Book on User-Friendly Design. What I See Today Horrifies Me," where he shed light on how the world is designed against the elderly.

By combining my personal journey, passion for fostering connections, and the power of games, I strive to make a meaningful impact and contribute to a more inclusive and harmonious society, where the young and the silver hair group can collaborate, learn from each other, and coexist in the digital world.
projects.technical_system:
Silver Valley utilizes the Unreal Engine with Blueprint to create a mobile application consisting of a game entrance and a community sub-page.

Extensive research was conducted on the challenges faced by the elderly, including visits to elderly communities. Interviews with the elderly were designed to co-create stories about animals. The game aims to maintain immersion within its magic circle and encourage player reflection. A community sub-page allows access to real animal stories and encourages contributions about the elderly. 

Game mechanics were built and tested early on, followed by user testing in multiple rounds. Milestones included proving mechanics, validating art style and demo story, and refining user experience. 

With limited time, AI was used to generate basic art assets and music, which would be adjusted manually as time permitted. This approach allowed for efficient content creation while maintaining flexibility for artistic enhancements.Used AI includes ChatGPT for text support, Midjourney for Art Assets, and Soundraw for music generation.

projects.elevator_pitch: Kleshas is a generative art project which aims to visualize and simulate negative emotions derived from Buddhist concepts in a virtual ecological environment.
projects.description:
Kleshas is a generative art made by Unity and it runs on a PC controlled by PICO 4 VR device. After wearing the VR device, users can see mainly five kinds of creatures flowing in the virtual space. Each of them performs different behaviors based on the theory of “Kleshas”(Attachment, Anger, Ignorance, Pride and Doubt). Also, emotion creatures have different materials and shapes. These five creatures are randomly generated and they compose an ecosystem. Audience can observe this environment on the VR platform. 

I am very interested in Buddhism, especially its interpretation of Kleshas(affliction or poison in English). Kleshas are the root of human’s unhappiness so i want to imitate a society that is filled with these negative emotions. When users dive into the virtual world, they will see a beautiful and harmonious environment that finally turns to be chaotic and disordered. By doing so, I hope my manifestation of negative emotions can let people reflect on themselves. We all have negative emotions in our daily life, however, we need to stop spreading our negative energy to others.
projects.background:
Brainstorm stage: at the beginning, I thought about doing something I am interested in which is buddhism. I looked at many different art styles related to buddhism. For example, I saw Haolin Kun’s DABEIYUZHOU, Yang Lu’s Delusional Crime and Punishment, Ian Cheng and Lawrence Lek’s art work, etc. However, I am not good at any of the art styles that I had thought. Then, I remember I had experience of generative art, so I decided to utilize programming which is what I am good at and combine coding with buddhism. Buddhism is such a large topic but the most impressive theory for me is called Kleshas. It influences my life a lot because it always reminds me to control my emotions, therefore, I quickly decided to make something about Kleshas.

Research stage: My research can be divided into three parts. For the first part, I looked for a concrete definition and explanation about Kleshas. This term appeared in many classical buddhist books such as 瑜伽师地论 and 唯識三十論頌. For the definition, Kleshas means affliction or poison and it usually has five kinds which are, attachment(excessive desire), anger(intense aversion, dislike, or hatred), ignorance(fundamental misunderstanding or misperception of the nature of reality), pride(inflated sense of self-importance, arrogance, or conceit) and doubt(indecision and 
skepticism). For some different sources, “wrong view” might also be part of Kleshas. For the second part of research, I looked at different ways of emotion visualization. I found that different colors, shapes and movements can be associated with different emotions.For the last part, I researched on specific artificial life algorithms such as steer, seek, separate, align, cohesion, wander, flocking, etc.
Prototyping stage: At the beginning, I set up the Unity project, including importing VR and shader related packages. Then mainly based on the research and study from The Nature of Code, I implemented basic A-life algorithms for every creature object I created. Based on the emotion state of each creature, they have different colors and shapes, and they also perform different movements. Finally, I roughly tested and debugged the prototype on VR in order to make sure the project at least could play. 
User test & Feedback loop: After showing my prototype to mentor, instructor and friends, I received feedback from different angles. The main problem for my thesis was it was hard for new users to distinguish different emotions. In order to solve this problem, I decided to improve the visual indication. There were some things I had done. First, I added tails and arms for each creature so that the user can see the movement track clearer. I utilized inverse kinematics to make them look smoother. Second, I changed the color for different creatures based on Plutchik's wheel of emotions(Attachment is yellow, anger is red, ignorance is light purple, pride is pink and doubt is green). Last, I changed different materials for the creatures. For every iteration, I kept user testing in order to make a better final version.
projects.technical_system: Kleshas is a VR project that runs on a PC(testing on AMD rx 6600 xt GPU) and needs to be controlled by a PICO4 VR device. For the display, the PC connects with a digital screen so that the audience can see and hear what is happening in the VR environment. It can only be used by one person at a time. Moveover, It will cost about 5 mins for each person to use it.  The thesis was developed by Unity Engine that was rendered by HRDP(High Definition Render Pipeline) and mainly programmed by using a boid algorithm and inverse kinematics.

projects.project_name: Excavating Eternal Beings - A Past Life Regression
projects.elevator_pitch: Audiovisual installation telling the story of my future incarnation on a past life regression, discovering the patterns throughout 9 lifetimes and continuing her life journey with a change.
projects.description: Audiovisual installation telling the story of my future incarnation on a past life regression, discovering the patterns throughout 9 lifetimes and continuing her life journey with a change. The video consists of 11 scenes total, a prologue, an epilogue, and 9 scenes in between. It is a personal project exploring my own psyche.
projects.background:
I’m interested in posthumanism, immortality in the sense of both physical (materials) and spiritual (beings). When I first started the project, my concept for the story was: when future sentient entities find my body after humans are extinct. What can they find out about our world through my remains? I knew I wanted to use my own image in this project instead of ready made 3d human models, because first of all I can manipulate my own image however I want without feeling guilty, and secondly I wanted to bring in my personal story. 

So the first thing I did was get a 3d scan of myself. At first I was a bit freaked out by looking at myself from a 3rd person view, but after spending weeks cleaning up the scan, applying a skeleton and working with skin texturing, I got used to it and started thinking about how my psyche is reflected in the way I render myself. 
And then I started putting my model in scenes that were just in my head. At this stage I got a lot of feedback or questions in regards to the aesthetic choices I tend to make. Like why am I always in a box, why is my posture always so closed off. Why put myself in chains and bondages in this sort of post-apocalyptic setting? What can I learn about myself  through analyzing the patterns? 
This is where I pivoted my project into a personal analysis. 

I realize the things I gravitate towards have something in common, isolation, constraints, loneliness, masochism, and the stagnant state of being in them. I came across this book Escape from freedom by social psychologist Erich Fromm which talks about human’s relationship with freedom, belongingness, and individuality. Here is a quote that I resonated with: “He is alone and free, yet powerless and afraid. The newly won freedom appears as a curse; he is free from the sweet bondage of paradise, but he is not free to govern himself, to realize his individuality”

This leads to my current central question: What is my relationship with freedom? What’s constraining me? How do I break out? And just to bring back my current concept for the story: My future incarnation on a past life regression, discovering the patterns throughout 9 lifetimes and continuing her life journey with a change.

projects.conclusion: The process of this project is in a way a long self-therapy session. Using my own image as the material has been an intimate and vulnerable experience, but at the same time it allowed me to see my subconscious surface, and the deep rooted, hidden conflicts within myself. I don’t have an answer for it yet, it is more of a diagnosis rather than prognosis. Another thing I learned is that a project doesn’t have an end, all the research, and unexpected pivots can branch out to many exciting possibilities.

projects.elevator_pitch: Interactive sculpture reflecting on humanity in the age of artificial intelligence and machine learning simulation.
projects.description: Daydreams of Simulacra is an audio sculpture that uses artificial intelligene to reflect simulated conversation and human connection back to the audience. By engaging with the piece’s multi-channel speaker chamber, the viewer is confronted with an overwhelming chorus of communication simulacra and prompted to explore the textures of the created audioscape.
projects.background:
Daydreams of Simulacra (2023) - An interactive generative audio sculpture that meditates on humanity in the age of machine intelligence.

This installation reflects my internal tension as I contemplate the future intersection of technology and society. Advances in artificial intelligence and generative media are reshaping our relationship with ourselves, blurring the boundaries between human and machine collaboration. As our tools begin to surpass our creative and cognitive capabilities, we are prompted to reconsider our understanding of what it means to be human. This piece offers a space for meditation on these intricate technical systems upon which we increasingly rely.

Powered by machine learning, the sculpture generates voicemail snippets to emulate human activity and connection. These snippets resonate through the 19 speakers within the sculpture's sound chamber, crafting an audioscape of imagined content. As the installation evolves, new voicemails are introduced, anchoring the experience in the viewers present moment.

If AI systems and large language models are fundamentally constructed from human input, how might these uncanny reflections offer glimpses, or even hallucinations, of our humanity?
projects.technical_system:
Daydreams of Simulacra is both a physical sculpture and a technical system. At it’s core, the technical system does the following: 

* Use a Large Language Model (LLM) to generate conversations between two people. Mother to Son, Sister to Sister, Student to Teacher, this system pulls from a model trained and fine-tuned on the collective and presents a sample of conversation. By using other sources of information ( news, weather, etc.) these conversations are grounded in present reality to keep the sculpture ‘alive’ as time continues. 

* Use a Text-To-Speech Model (TTS) to move from written script to audio. The TTS model continually captures audio from the internet and the installation room to create new voice models, and adds the voice to the sculpture’s ‘collection’. These voices are then used to generate future conversations.

* Playing the generated audio files through speakers distributed through the sculpture’s membrane. By playing multiple audio clips in parallel, the viewer is continually surrounded by the audio waves of conversation. At the same time, conversations in the installation room also become part of the soundscape, blending in to the simulated collection of speech.

projects.project_name: Don’t Look At Me When I’m Coding
projects.elevator_pitch: As a programmer, the artist perceives coding as a delightful craft. This installation seeks to discuss the place and emotions of individuals in their work, regardless of the nature of the job or the era.
projects.description:
In an age of artificial intelligence, perhaps we are the last generation of manual coders. This art installation captures the essence of our craft and the spirit of the artisan in coding, particularly focusing on the amusing reality that I become uncomfortable when others watch me code. The installation involves two laptops: one displaying a replay of my coding process which halts as soon as an audience observes it, mirroring my own behavior when coding under watchful eyes.

Behind this laptop, a second machine churns out AI-generated code, but with an intriguing twist. It only generates code when observed, standing in stark contrast to the human vulnerability and embarrassment that halts the first machine. This stark dichotomy is designed to highlight the unique human qualities that persist even in an AI-dominated era.

The exhibit poses an important question to its audience: In the age of AI, what should we preserve and what should we update? This isn’t just an exploration of the craft of coding; it's a conversation starter about the future of humanity and the intersection of AI and human emotions. It pays homage to the fact that even in a world inundated with AI, the human factor remains integral and irreplaceable.
projects.background:
The inspiration for this project is rooted in the exploration of how human emotions and the growth of AI intersect, particularly in the field of coding, which is often seen as purely logical and devoid of emotion.

Researching the artisan spirit found within the coding community revealed that despite its technological nature, coding is not just about writing functional lines of code. It's about problem-solving, creativity, and a certain sense of pride and ownership in one's work. Like an artist uncomfortable with being watched while painting, many coders feel uneasy when observed during the act of creation.

In the context of our rapidly evolving digital age, AI is increasingly being used to automate tasks, including code generation. The question then arises: What happens to the human aspect of coding in the face of AI automation? Will the AI understand the artisan spirit of coding?

Against this backdrop, the project seeks to bring these conversations to the forefront, provoking contemplation about the balance between human emotion and the unemotional efficiency of AI. By making use of eye tracking and AI code generation, the project serves as a reminder of our inherent human nature, even in an age defined by technology.
projects.technical_system:
Technically, this project integrates computer vision and artificial intelligence to create an interactive exhibit that responds to human presence. The laptops employ their built-in cameras for eye tracking, determining whether someone is watching the screens.

On the first laptop, a script replays the process of me coding. The eye tracking function interrupts this replay as soon as it detects an observer, simulating my discomfort when watched while coding.

Conversely, the second laptop uses an AI model to generate code, but uniquely, it only does so when an observer is detected. This is designed to contrast the machine's indifference to being observed with the human feeling of vulnerability under scrutiny.

The use of eye tracking in conjunction with AI code generation transforms this installation from a static exhibit into an interactive exploration of human-AI interaction.

projects.description: Before the Sun Rises is an online multiplayer game designed to encourage altruistic and prosocial behavior between strangers. In the current landscape of primarily competitive multiplayer games, how do we design a game that encourages kind, compassionate and generous behavior, but also provides a sense of agency while doing so?
projects.background: Multiplayer games that created positive and cooperative player interactions, like Journey, Death Stranding, and One Hour One Life, are very inspirational to me. There’s something that feels wonderful and also uncommon when seeing positive interactions between strangers online in a game. What made one game more “friendly” and “safe” versus another, and what aspect of the game design influenced that feeling? Through several play tests, I attempted to create my own altruistic game by changing the level design, UI, game mechanics, and system structure. My definition for altruism in this particular game was the act of sharing knowledge and helping other players find resources on the map.
projects.technical_system: My initial low-tech prototypes were done in Miro, an online collaboration tool. The final game is made in Unreal Engine 5 with the Steam online subsystem. Players can download a demo of the game on Steam, and either play solo or with another player. Animations were done with Mixamo and Unreal's animation tools, and the intro cutscene was drawn and animated by using Procreate and After Effects.
projects.conclusion: Designing a game for altruism proved to be a difficult challenge, and to me, and ongoing one. But through watching various reactions to people playing the game, I feel more sure than ever that there is space to evolve the definition of what a game can be, the gaming communities surrounding them, and in what way they can be used. Ultimately, I wish to see more gaming communities, and communities outside of them, embrace compassionate, helpful, and generous acts. By designing a game for altruism, I hope to share more of those values amongst those who are looking for a gaming experience beyond the norm.

projects.project_name: Nesting: The Non-Human Technology of Bird Nests
projects.elevator_pitch: Learning from the non-human technologies, extraordinary craft, and ritual behaviors involved in birds’ practice of building nests and creating homes.
projects.description: I spent several weeks studying the nest-building behavior of birds, examining the ways in which they build homes and the technologies they have developed in order to do so. This began as an exercise in considering how a specific non-human species, birds, intelligently solves craft-based problems, and became an emotive exploration of the elements that creatures – human and non-human alike — use to build homes.
projects.background:
I began my research by thinking about how examples of technology show up in the non-human animal world. I started by reading James Bridle’s Ways of Being, A Search for Planetary Intelligence, and simultaneously began researching animal craftscreatures. Although many options of excellence in craft amongst members of the animal world were available, I quickly gravitated toward birds. My sister and mother have recently been taking me along on birdwatching walks, so birds were a personally relevant topic for me in this sense. 

I read about birds adapting their migratory behavior and nest building because of climate change, the ways in which bird nest material selection is changing during the anthropocene, and the many ways that birds solve specific problems through the craft of building their nests. I reveled in learning about how bushtits use spider silk to create a flexible, elastic home that can grow as the baby birds grow. I was surprised to see tailorbirds sewing leaves together with plant fibers, as I had thought sewing was a uniquely human practice. 

Through this research, I realized that there are so many things that humans could learn from birds. Surely a bird could serve as an example for architecture, engineering, adaptation, survival, craft, art, and more. This prompted me to think about this exercise as a component of a course taught by birds – not only what would they teach, but why would they teach humans? What else could humans learn from birds, and why should we? What’s in it for the birds? I began thinking about design pedagogy, interrogating human centered design, and looking at other artists who are dealing with alternative approaches to learning from and with nature. Some of these artists include Andrea Zittel, Jen Delos Rios, Mary Mattingly, and Julie Chen. 

While birds could serve as core faculty for anything from a design school to an engineering school, I came to this exercise as an artist and craftsperson. And as an artist and craftsperson who spent most of the last year traveling, the things I learned from these bird lessons centered around how to build a home.
projects.technical_system:
My project is manifested in a series of physical objects, nest maquettes, and a workshop. In response to what I was studying, I built maquettes interpreting bird nests out of old garments including jeans, flannel pants, my family members’ uncoupled socks, and my partner’s old shoes. I used found objects for additional elements, and I followed the processes that birds use like sewing, weaving, matting, and tying. I then built boxes as housing for these nests using chipboard and calligraphy paper, creating a series of doors and drawers to encourage exploration and curiosity. 

I also built an audio-imbued scarf as an abstracted nest concept. I took a 24 hour audio feed from the front window of my home in Chicago, and used microcontrollers and speakers to incorporate it into a scarf, in order to explore the auditory dimension of what contributes to a sense of home. If one is in San Francisco, what does it feel like to be listening to the street sounds of Chicago?

Finally, I created a workshop to explore nest building with my classmates. I wanted to formalize what I was learning from birds into a lesson for others, so I created a youtube playlist, discussion prompts for conversation, and a nest-making prototype session.

projects.elevator_pitch: A digital application that generates audio-visual experiences for the elderly to use for personal practices, aiming to help them sleep better, feel more relaxed and positive via nature therapy and music therapy.
projects.description:
My thesis project surrounds the topic of enhancing elderly’s mental wellbeing - particularly on how a digital application can help them relieve anxiety, improve mood and sleep well. The product delivers an audio-visual experience, aiming to provide elderly the access to specific video content (a combination of nature therapy and music therapy). 

My intention comes from my grandparents as recently they are starting to live alone sometimes, and post-COIVD they faced a change to their lifestyle - spending more time at home and feeling less sense of companionship. My grandma also told me her sleep quality is getting worse. She sometimes has to rely on melatonin to fall asleep quicker, and also tend to wake up in the middle of night. How might they sleep better, and feel less anxious, bored, lonely at home? Because of my close connection with my grandparents, I want to use my previous knowledge and experience on product design, in addition to what I learned from this master’s program on interactive media, to create something meaningful and make their daily lives better & healthier. This might sound more of a personal project, but I hope what I designed can also benefit other elders with similar needs. 

Another intention is that I want to explore the topic of technology on the elder generation, especially how we can use technology to its most optimal extent so that elders would not feel overwhelmed. Therefore, this project not only focuses on the curation of effective video content but also explores user interface design and the format of display. The product form is a digital application with 2 types of interfaces: mobile touch screen and TV with remote control. They both provide access to beautiful nature videos with instrumental music and nature sounds. I programmed in p5.js using the machine learning method to add in a voice-control function where the elderly can choose which type of nature sounds they want to listen to. The code runs in the background; so while the video and music are continuously playing, different nature sounds (birds, wind, rain, etc.) can tune in anywhere based on their voice command.
projects.background:
Due to the special audience type, goal, and having a hard time deciding on the product form, I followed the Human-Centered Design methodology called the Lean Methodology - researching and making at the same time with lots of iterations on my idea. When specifying the audience, I realized all people might have different needs, so I decided to solely use my grandparents as the persona for my product, specifically for the early interviews and user testings on the content and interface.

My background research was quite broad as I wanted to gather as much information as possible to help with my brainstorming & ideation process. I dived into many topics: nature therapy, music therapy, successful aging, mental wellness improvement, effectiveness of immersive experiences for the elderly, apps designed for the elderly, innovative products and devices to help seniors live happier, etc. I was inspired by some similar projects that all focus on mental wellbeing - they either are designed for the elderly audience or have the meditative audiovisual nature content that I wanted to explore. One is the Multisensory Interactive Window that strives to enhance the older adult's well-being at home. The system allows communicating with distant people through a tangible installation. Another example is Torin Blankensmith’s QLab project, an immersive & interactive experience using nature, AI and ML on a projector to facilitate patients' mental treatment. The setting is in a healthcare center's wellness room. Torin’s Quantum Summer is also a relevant project, which is a web-based audio-visual interactive experience (controlled with mouse and keyboard, like a game) that provides a meditative journey through the stars. All of these references facilitated my initial storyboard & mood-board development.

A special influence was the NYU Aging Incubator, which I utilized as a professional resource and expertise. Talking with doctors and nurses offered me insights on therapy, meditation and technology’s role on mental wellness. Our conversation reinforces my idea of using nature & music therapy for my video content. I also learned that the level of interactivity and immersiveness can be minimized for the elderly group of audience. How I eventually decided on the product from was from a survey I conducted after talking with the NYU Aging Incubator. I received lots of useful data and positive responses on TV and mobile interface, display, as well as the effectiveness of nature & music to alleviate loneliness and anxiety.
projects.technical_system:
My project is a digital product in the form of a mobile application, along with a TV program. Mobile and TV display the same content, just with different interfaces. I try to make it more accessible so it gives elderly the option to choose which way they prefer (phone and touch screen vs. TV and remote control, or both). The TV program functions like the Youtube & Netflix plug-ins. It would be suitable for at-home settings with less mobility, but the mobile APP has more dynamic use with less limitation on where and when to use. 

I’m mainly using Figma, and Photoshop for the UI design and mock-up part. I explored Sketch & Invision as well, but ended up using Figma. The Figma prototype has some level of interactivity, but to make it fully functional, have more user interactions, and connect with the video content, I will need web/APP development skills, including intensive programming in HTML/CSS/Javascript. But for my current scope, APP development is minimal. I only utilized p5.js and Teachable Machine (machine learning AI) to program the part where users can control the sound of nature using voice. The music and visuals stays on unless they manually stop them, but the voice control allows them to choose what type of nature sounds they want to add in (rain, wind, bird, etc.) to the experience. To better facilitate the storytelling of the user experience and how the product is used, I filmed and edited a short video with Premier Pro to depict the user journey in a clear and engaging way.

projects.elevator_pitch: I’ve created a soundscape protocol and series of soundbaths that guide audience members into elusive states of consciousness with my real-time heart and brainwave activity.
projects.description:
After 4 years of performing brainwave-powered techno, I came to NYU to research a number of consciousness-expanding experiences that emerged spontaneously during my shows. I reviewed my journal entries and video recordings of those shows, honing in on the use of repetitive beats. I researched how they impact consciousness and performed experiments where I listened to the same beat for an hour and observed an increase in “theta” brainwave levels. This increase indicates a trance state where the brain is dreaming yet still awake. I designed a soundscape protocol that induces a theta state. Finally, I performed a series of soundbaths using sounds from my live heart and brainwave data. These experiences entrained the audience members to my biometrics and guided them into elusive states of consciousness.  

I was drawn to this work because of the intimacy of live biofeedback. When I performed techno in the past - as long as I pressed the keys at the right time - no one knew what I was feeling. With biofeedback music, the audience knows. This vulnerability is a refreshing contrast to the dehumanization I typically feel when using technology.

I’m also interested in this work because of its power to recreate elusive states of consciousness without the use of mind-altering drugs. During my childhood, I felt safer being in my head rather than in the real world, which was sometimes dangerous. Imagination, fantasy, and music were safe places for me. In my late teens I became a “psychonaut,” exploring the far reaches of my mind with drug use. My music also reflected this, using experimental compositions to push the listener’s mind. At age 20, I found meditation, another exploratory tool. These methods satisfied a deep curiosity of the unknown and a desire to master my mind, thoughts, and emotions.
projects.technical_system:
I’ve created a soundscape protocol and implemented it in a series of immersive audio and visual performances, using a “soundbath” format where visitors lie down, close their eyes, and listen to a soundscape generated by my live heart and brainwave activity. 

I’m using a Muse headset that detects my brainwave activity with EEG sensors and my heart activity with a PPG sensor. This biometric data is sent via bluetooth to my computer where it’s processed by a custom software I built in Swift and output as MIDI and DMX. The MIDI is sent to Ableton and rendered into a soundscape which adheres to either a “theta” relaxation protocol or a “peak” stimulation protocol. The DMX is sent to theater lights that pulse with my heart and change color based on my mental state.

Because human bodies tend to synchronize to dominant biological signals, my amplified biometrics often entrain the minds and hearts of the visitors. This produces a group synchrony experience where most of the visitors are experiencing the same thing. 

The performance is followed by a group discussion, giving visitors the opportunity to share their experiences and ask questions.

We live in an era of cheap digital storage, online-first everything, and widespread use of artificial intelligence. Personal data collection has become excessive, and with it - I believe we face an increased risk of harm.  The more we rely on the internet, the more data governments and companies accumulate about us. At the same time, their ability to process that data quickly, cheaply, and intelligently is improving rapidly with recent advancements in A.I. 
 
Earlier in my career, I worked on news feed personalization at Facebook.  The models that I helped build there would train on a user's entire history of interactions (every click, scroll, and view from Facebook, Instagram, any website with a Facebook cookie). We developed a best-in-class understanding of our users' interests. These "interest profiles" - as we called them - help Facebook deliver hyper personalized content to keep people scrolling. Over time, I became increasingly uncomfortable with the impact of my work and concerned with how widespread “surveillance capitalism” has become. Addictive technology and invasive targeting has the power to control people, communities, and democracies.

Big data is invisible and (in the US) the entities that aggregate, manipulate, and sell information about us are also often invisible. Because digital rights regulation in the United States is severely lacking, managing one’s vast and distributed volume of personal data can feel hopeless. 

This work is an attempt to manifest my own digital footprint into a physical form for the sole purpose of imagined destruction. My hope is that “Delete Me” not only has the power to educate viewers on the scale and distributed nature of mass data collection in the United States, but that its interactive components also provide an emotional outlet for those of us wrestling with the impracticality of digital privacy in modern society.
projects.background:
This project is my entry-point into thinking about data collection critically and doing it from a personal lens. Much of my research was focused on the systems of commercial digital tracking and profiling that exist in the United States and abroad. I also incorporated my experiences as a software engineer and AI researcher embedded in Silicon Valley, where I saw firsthand how personal information is collected, handled, and shared - typically without care for the individual. User data is recorded constantly, aggregated from many sources, inferences are made, and this information is shared between platforms and companies. Most people have no insight into this system, and none of us have much recourse.

I look to the principles of GDPR (the EU’s General Data Protection Regulation), as a reference for what is possible in the realm of digital rights. In particular, I am frustrated with how the US falls short on the principles of storage minimization, data retention, and the “right to be forgotten.” Data brokers are not only legal in the US, but major government agencies are some of their top customers. The US Defense Intelligence Agency, Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency, and Customs and Border Protection (CBP) are among a wide range of federal entities known to purchase our personal data. 

One of my biggest artistic inspirations for this work is Sarah Sze, who produces art exploring our relationship with the digital / physical boundary and manages to turn objects of clutter into fine art. To me, there exists a strong parallel between excess digital data collection and physical hoarding. 

Other sources of inspiration include: Jennifer Morone, who made herself into a corporation to protect her personal data; and Owen Mundy, who employs a thermal printer to shed light on mass data aggregation and the commodification of online users in his piece *Terms and Conditions of Use (2013).*
projects.technical_system:
“Delete Me” is an interactive sculpture. I first manifest my own digital footprint into a physical form and then invite participants to help me “delete” it. The project has taken on two forms thus far. The first version was a paper-based installation in New York City in May 2023; the second: a food-based sculpture, “Del(eat) Me”, in Shanghai June 2023. 

My work began with some simple questions: What data can I find about myself? How can I process & reproduce that data physically to emphasize scale? 

I attempted to catalogue all websites and technology platforms I have ever used. I requested and downloaded over 50GB of data from Amazon, Meta, Google, Apple, Venmo, TikTok, Airbnb, Verizon, Uber, Hinge, and Epsilon (a data broker). I used Python to process, compress, and reformat the data. I then performed a series of “manifest and destroy” experiments with different physical materials. I landed on a combination of thermal paper, manual shredding, and black paint as the best materials balancing safety and satisfaction. This formed the foundation of the NYC installation, where I printed all 50+GB onto thermal receipt paper, and invited the public to shred/tear/paint/rip it. 

For version 2, I wanted to use a more playful and inviting medium, where my data was actually legible. For this installation, I made the most of NYU Shanghai's new maker-space and experimented with laser cutting edible objects. The result: I turned my most intimate snippets of internet search history into a bountiful breadbasket for the public to consume.
projects.conclusion:
I came into this work with the hypothesis that people would care a lot more about their digital footprint (from a privacy and utility standpoint) if they saw it manifested in a physical form.

In the NYC installation, I was able to teach participants about the data collection ecosystem in the Unites States and spark dozens of fruitful conversations about digital rights. To promote action, the exhibit included a plate of cookies with QR codes printed on them - a physical manifestation of browser cookies - directing viewers to [deletemydata.io](http://deletemydata.io/), where they could find instructions on how to remove themselves from various data marketplace websites. Viewers resonated with the work - they understood how deleting this one physical manifestation does nothing just as removing your data from a single company does not guarantee universal deletion. They felt satisfaction cranking the paper shredder, ripping receipts off the wires, and covering data with thick black paint. The sculpture evolved over the course of the 2-day exhibit into a wonderful chaotic mess. 

I believe the NYC edition of Delete Me successfully conveyed the overwhelming scale of the data and demonstrated the value of collective destruction. However, it relied on exaggerated fear and anger to paint an oversimplified picture of all data collection as bad - all data as something that should be erased. 

With the Shanghai edition of Del(eat) Me, I set out to make the data itself legible - highlighting selective files that I actually wish to delete - and to experiment with a more playful form of deletion: eating. I pulled search query history from a Google account that I have actively used since middle school, and printed my searches onto slices of bread. Unfortunately, bread adopts a rather sour taste when laser cut and the internet disagrees on wether or not it is safe to eat, so I wasn't able to capture the public consumption of my internet search history as initially intended. 

Nevertheless, viewers found the installation entertaining and provocative. The search queries were relatable and entertaining, although lacked an explicit educational component to provide context on the larger digital tracking ecosystem. The tone of Version 2 was lighter and the takeaways were more abstract. This was important to me given the cultural and political differences around privacy in China vs the US. For many, the exhibit was simply cute & funny. But for some - it prompted more serious discussions on data surveillance. One viewer even came back for the second day of the show because he kept ruminating on the exhibit and wanted to ask me "Why bread?" 

I chose to work with food because I wanted to introduce a sense of levity to an otherwise distressing topic. Bread is a basic building block of meals around the world - a universal symbol of sharing. I spent months researching all of the ways that data collection can cause harm and our lack of control over it. But Internet history - my data - doesn’t need to be so scary. I chose to put my most intimate web history on display for the public so that the data itself would become less daunting. 

Through this work I have come to accept that my data will be collected and shared beyond my control, making the fight for controls and protections even more important. I remain passionate about digital rights and plan to continue researching in this space. In particular iterating on my central question: What is the impact of experiencing one's data in a physical form?

projects.elevator_pitch: An interactive installation aims to challenge and provoke critical reflection on facial emotion recognition systems, highlighting the complex nature of emotions and the potential risks associated with such technology.
projects.description: This project presents an innovative physical installation designed to provoke contemplation on the intricate nature of emotions. By employing a camera and a facial emotion recognition system, the installation records and analyzes individuals who participate, generating comprehensive prediction reports encompassing attributes such as age, gender, race, emotion, mental health, and overall score. These reports are printed out using a continuous printer, and individuals are assigned scores based on a meticulously developed algorithm. Participants can choose to take away the report or pin it on the wall for reference. The primary objective of this project is to encourage a deeper understanding of emotions by considering their diverse expressions and the potential risks associated with facial emotion recognition technology and artificial intelligence biases. Furthermore, it prompts critical questioning regarding the necessity of utilizing facial emotion recognition to predict inner feelings, assess dependability, conscientiousness, emotional intelligence, and cognitive ability, thereby envisioning a future where every facial expression is automatically analyzed.
projects.technical_system: The project's implementation involves an anti-technology stance towards facial emotion recognition systems. The classifier, developed using Python, TensorFlow, and other Open-Source API models, simulates a comprehensive health assessment process. This process encompasses data measurement, evaluation, emotion analysis, and inference of psychological well-being. Each user's facial and emotion recognition, psychological state analysis, comprehensive evaluation, and printing functions are iteratively performed to provide tangible paper reports for participants to take away. The algorithmic scoring system, tailored specifically for this project, forms the basis for assigning scores and delivering holistic evaluations and recommendations.

projects.project_name: FutureCraft: A Collaborative World Building System
projects.elevator_pitch: FutureCraft is a collaborative card game that uses AR to help players explore the potential consequences of their decisions and build a better future together.
projects.description:
FutureCraft is a collaborative future world building card game designed to explore the potential consequences of our decisions and build a better future together. This game uses AR technology to visualize the future world created by players, making it a dynamic and engaging experience that encourages players to think critically about the world around them.

In FutureCraft, players assume the role of architects of the future, working together to build a world based on their collective decisions. Each player must consider the impact of their choices on four key areas: economy, environment, society, and technology. By reflecting on the world they've built, players can gain valuable insights into the complex interplay of factors that shape our world and learn more about their own decision-making process.

The game is designed for 2-4 players, and encourages collaboration, role-playing, and strategic thinking. Each game session is unique, as the decisions made by players will determine the outcome of the future world they create. This makes the game not only engaging, but also highly informative and thought-provoking.

FutureCraft is an ideal tool for anyone interested in exploring the future and the impact of our decisions on the world around us. Whether you're a student, a researcher, or simply a curious individual looking to gain a deeper understanding of the world, this game is sure to provide a valuable and engaging experience.
projects.background:
One of the key elements that drew me to board games is the focus on decision making. I believe that the choices people make have a significant impact on the future, and I wanted to create a game that would inspire players to think critically about how their decisions and actions affect the world around them. By designing a future world building board game, I hope to encourage players to reflect on the present and consider what they can do as individuals to create a better world. My goal is to develop a fun and engaging game that combines education and gamification, while also inspiring players to think about the future in a meaningful way.

For my research, I mainly focused on these aspects: future world building, game design and game based learning. The science fiction "The Three-Body Problem" by Liu Cixin was one of my key inspirations on future world design. It explores how humans would react and respond to alien civilizations, which resonate with the idea of decision-making scenarios in my own game. "The Wandering Earth 2" , one of my favorite science fiction movies, also presented an interesting future scenario of humans moving the earth away from the solar system to save it from the sun's destruction. The "Investing in Futures" website tool provided another great example of world building through card selection in different categories. All these science fiction and futuristic worlds inspired me to design the content of my cards.

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are also an important part of my content creation. They were addressed by the United Nations, which aim to promote peace and prosperity for people and the planet. These goals inspired me to create card contents that encourage players to reflect on how their decisions can affect the future and work towards a more sustainable world.

I also researched and did user testing on different forms and gaming mechanisms. Initially I was inspired by The "Life Restart Simulator" game, as it generates a timeline based on initial parameters set by the player, which could be useful for generating future scenarios in my game. While doing user testing and presentations, I received feedback on adding different roles to the game to simulate social decision making. Role playing also enables players to put themselves in others' shoes and think about making different decisions. To better understand role playing, I also researched role playing games such as  "Murder Mystery Game" and “Dungeons and Dragons”.

In terms of technical research, I explored open-source AI models for image generation like Midjourney to help create visuals for my cards. In addition, "Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters", one of my favorite card games and animation, provided inspiration for the immersive design elements of my game. And to realize that experience, I used Vuforia in Unity to build an AR app for visualization of the world building process, while combining the physical card game with a virtual world construction space.

projects.technical_system:
There are three main parts within FutureCraft: the physical card game system, AR visualization and a virtual judge. 

The physical card game system is the backbone of the Future World Simulator. All the visuals on the cards are generated using AI by Midjourney, and each depicts an action or event that could happen in the future. During gameplay, players use these cards to make decisions that shape the collective future world. The cards are designed to represent four key categories: economy, environment, society, and technology.

The AR visualization component of the game provides a dynamic and immersive experience for players. After a card is played, players can see the visualization of that action in the AR space. The AR app is built using Vuforia in Unity, and allows players to see the consequences of their decisions in real-time. 

The virtual judge is another crucial component of the game, as it allows players to see how their decisions impact the future world they are building. The system uses Teachable Machine to train all the visuals of the cards, and ml5 in p5.js to recognize the cards and calculate their points for the four categories: economy, environment, society, and technology. When a player shows the card they played to the webcam, the system automatically recognizes the card and calculates the points.
projects.conclusion:
In conclusion, my thesis project aimed to combine education with gamification by creating a future world building board game that encourages players to think critically about how their decisions and actions can impact the world around them. Through my research, I explored various works of science fiction, game design, and game-based learning to inspire and inform the design of the game.

I drew inspiration from science fiction works like "The Three-Body Problem" and "The Wandering Earth 2" to create a compelling future world that players could interact with and explore. The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) were also an important part of the game's content, as they provided a framework for players to think about how their decisions could contribute to a more sustainable world.

My research and user testing also led me to incorporate role-playing elements into the game, which allowed players to put themselves in different scenarios and think about making different decisions. Additionally, I used open-source AI models and AR technology to enhance the game's visuals and create an immersive world-building experience for players.

Throughout the course of this project, I learned a great deal about game design, world building, and the intersection of education and gamification. I discovered that creating a game that is both fun and educational requires a careful balance of design elements and content, as well as an understanding of user behavior and feedback.

Overall, I am proud of the work I have done on this project and believe that it has the potential to inspire players to think more critically about the future and their role in shaping it. I hope that this game can be used in classrooms, community centers, and other educational settings to engage and inspire learners of all ages.

projects.elevator_pitch:
How to deal with the pervasive and unavoidable anxiety in my life?
“When you gaze into the abyss, the abyss also gazes at you." So it is with Anxiety.
projects.description:
"The Wheel of Anxiety" is a web experience that invites participants to engage with a mesmerizing visual graphic consisting of texts and symbolic representations of "Anxiety." It explores the relationship between individuals and the pervasive and unavoidable Anxiety in contemporary Chinese society.

Anxiety is always there and cannot be eradicated. The more one focuses on it, the more confusion and unrest it brings. Why not, instead, cease the gaze?
projects.background:
Driven by global capitalism and rapid technological development, our world pushes individuals to pursue ever-higher levels of productivity and efficiency. The constant drive for productivity and efficiency can leave individuals feeling anxious, overwhelmed, and even lost, especially in contemporary China, a rapidly developing country in the past decades. 

I wanted to find answers to unravel the confusion: Is it technology that exacerbates individuals' anxiety in their daily life? How can I discover a balance and cultivate a calm inner state in such a fast-paced and anxiety-filled society? I started the journey of exploration through research and experimentation.

In my research, there are three main phases.

Phase 1:  Understanding wellness
- Understanding the definition and dimension of wellness
- Identifying the impact of technology development on human well-being. 
Through Phase-1 research, I worked out a framework to help myself to be aware of my routine with wellbeing status.

Phase 2: Understanding individual’s daily routine in the form of visualization
- Record my daily routine by Shape Journal 
- Conduct interviews to gain a deeper understanding of individuals' perceptions of anxiety, their daily routines, and how they cope with anxiety.
 
Phase 3: Express and interpret my anxiety from a new perspective 
- Create an interactive artistic graphic for expression
projects.technical_system: "The Wheel of Anxiety" is a web experience, using p5js and ml5.js. Through the exploration of the visual graphic, instinctively, participants will firstly fix their gaze on the screen, observing the transformation of the "Wheel of Anxiety" as texts and symbols gradually fill the entire display. However, if participants close their eyes and cease to behold it, the "Wheel of Anxiety" will cease its expansion, transitioning into a state of contraction. The texts and symbols representing Anxiety, though persistent, will take on a relatively stable format.
projects.conclusion:
It all started with my story - as a sales and marketing professional and also a working mom in the high-tech industry, I have been used to pursuing extreme efficiency. I plan my time down to the minute and multitask as a habit. Especially after taking the LowRes IMA program, there was even a period of time when I planned my time with utmost precision.

Although I strictly followed my "perfectly efficient" schedule, the result was that I felt even more endless anxiety and unease. I felt like I couldn't breathe, and my time lost its rhythm. 

In the past few months, I am not only working on my thesis and projects, but also have embarked on a journey of self-exploration. Through the research on wellness and the impact of technology development on wellness, the introspection of my own daily routine and status, and engaging with individuals with similar challenges and feelings, I have finally completed my interpretation of anxiety and also found a dynamic balance in my daily life.

projects.elevator_pitch: Extending the impact and reach of live theatre and performance beyond the limitations of a physical stage.
projects.description: What began as an exploration of a low tech form of interactive theatre (Theatre of the Oppressed) evolved into performing Theatre of the Oppressed with digital engagement, using live streams and VR. Theatre of the Oppressed seeks to blur the lines between audience and actor through active participation; empowering the audience to be able to make a change both in the art that they consume and in the world around them. My goal with the digital engagement is to broaden the reach of this kind of work--work that has proved to be a powerful and subversive tool in a live format--and to enable those outside of the physical space where it's performed to take part in it.
projects.background: Theatre of the Oppressed is an umbrella term for various theatrical forms that seek to empower audience members to make change, as active participants in both the art they're taking part of and the world around them, through rehearsal of dealing with oppressive situations. In this workshop I'll be facilitating two of these forms, the first being Image Theatre and the second and primary form being Forum Theatre. In Image Theatre a frozen image is edited and iterated on live to steer it away from oppression. In Forum Theatre scenes of oppression are played out using audience members as actors; one time through with no engagement and then again several times over with the audience having the opportunity to call "freeze" and make suggestions to change the script or action, offering different solutions to the oppressive situations.
projects.user_scenario: A live audience will be able to offer changes to the Forum Theatre scenes in person, or to be able to step in and take the place of an actor to change the action in the scene. Digital audience members (without VR headsets) will be able to suggest changes to the script via a chat feed, while digital audience members (with a VR headset) will be able to "step in" and engage with the workshop as if they were physically present via the live stream using the 360 degree camera.
projects.technical_system: A condensed workshop on Theatre of the Oppressed will be performed in the XR space on campus. It will be blocked around a 360 degree camera with live streaming capabilities, and captured on video by a single direction camera that's also incorporated into the live stream. Audience members not physically present will be able to tune in via the 360 degree camera with VR headsets, enabling them to step in as if they were present. Audience members without VR headsets will be able to engage via the live stream on Youtube, able to comment and suggest changes to the action and the script via the chat.
projects.project_references: Theatre of the Oppressed was devised by Augusto Boal, and laid out in his book of the same name. The streamed engagement (both VR and chat) was demoed with the help of Jesse Yu at NYU Shanghai.

projects.project_name: Merging Worlds: bridging analog and digital photography
projects.elevator_pitch: Inspired by my personal experiences as a software engineer and analog photographer, this project is a personally crafted camera that blends the tactile charm of analog photography with discreet incorporation of digital features.
projects.description:
This project embarks on a personal journey, intertwining my passion for analog photography with my identity as a software engineer. For the longest time, I believed these two realms were mutually exclusive, forcing me to make a choice between them. However, through my involvement in the IMA Low Res program, I began to see the shades of gray between the black and white. I envisioned a world where my passions could harmoniously coexist.
The spark of inspiration ignited when I decided to reimagine my most treasured possession—the camera. Drawing inspiration from the cherished analog models that have influenced my craft, I set out to design a camera that uses the tactile allure of analog cameras but also seamlessly integrates digital capabilities. It would use a waist-level viewfinder to serve as the primary interface for framing photos. But concealed within is a Raspberry Pi, discreetly capturing images in digital form.
However, my exploration extended beyond the hardware itself. I delved deep into the realms of photography theory and the psychology behind sharing images on social media platforms. As someone who predominantly shares their work online, I was often disheartened by the battle against algorithms to gain visibility and validation. The relentless pursuit of likes and followers began to overshadow the intrinsic value of my creations. I wanted to redefine the way I share my work.
Thus, alongside the camera, I designed and built a website to display the photos taken from my camera. Instead of a polished and professional portfolio, I aimed for a space that encourages authenticity and rawness of my everyday moments. Inspired by experimental web design, I infused elements of skeuomorphism to instill a sense of tangibility in the digital realm.
projects.background:
This project originated from my desire to merge two significant aspects of my life: analog photography and software development. Additionally, I aimed to critically examine and enhance the role of social media in sharing photography work. As an online photographer, particularly on platforms like Instagram, I have experienced frustration and discouragement due to the competitive nature of social media algorithms.

During the research phase, I broke down the aspects of photography into three parts: photograph-making, photograph-sharing, and photograph-consuming. I explored each of these areas by reading books, prototyping ideas, and reflecting on my own experiences. 

In the photograph-making phase of my research, I read books from the Ansel Adams Photography Photography Series, which includes The Camera, The Negative, and The Print. Published in the 1950s, each book of the series is a deep dive into the technical aspects of analog photography. The descriptions and diagrams from these books helped me envision the mechanics of an analog camera, and gave me ideas on how to incorporate them into my design. 

In the photograph-sharing phase of my research, I turned to "The Social Photo" by Nathan Jurgenson. Jurgenson's thought-provoking insights shed light on the impact of social media on our understanding and engagement with photography. He delves into topics such as the transformation of images into data, the rise of the "selfie," and the construction of identity in the digital age. Drawing from Jurgenson's perspectives, I critically examined the role of social media platforms, particularly Instagram, in shaping the perception and value of photographic work. His work inspired me to challenge the constraints of algorithmic validation and explore alternative modes of sharing and experiencing photography. A particular quote that resonated with me was, “In the age of digital abundance, photography desperately needs this introduction of intentional and assured morality, so that some photos can become immortal again.”

During the photograph-consuming phase of my research, I ventured beyond theoretical readings and engaged in practical exploration. I examined online photography communities, and analyzed the behavior and preferences of social media users. This immersive approach enabled me to gain a nuanced understanding of the ways in which individuals engage with and derive meaning from photographs in the digital realm.

Based on my research and personal insights, I set out to create a camera that combines the charm of analog photography with modern digital features. Taking inspiration from the wisdom of Ansel Adams and the thought-provoking ideas of Nathan Jurgenson, I aimed to design a tool that helps people connect more deeply with the art of photography and breaks away from the usual ways of sharing images online.

By incorporating the workings of analog cameras into my design, I aimed to provide photographers with a hands-on and immersive experience. At the same time, I ventured into fresh approaches for sharing my work online, steering away from the controlled and algorithm-dependent nature of mainstream platforms. Drawing inspiration from Jurgenson's insights on social media and the formation of identity, I envisioned a digital realm that embraces genuineness and fosters deeper connections with photography.
projects.technical_system:
This project provided an invaluable opportunity for me to acquire new skill sets that I had long desired to learn. It began with sketching and constructing an initial cardboard prototype to verify the technical feasibility of the waist-level viewfinder mechanics. Progressing further, I utilized a laser cutter to craft a refined prototype with an acrylic body. I delved into working with a Raspberry Pi, gaining proficiency in flashing an OS on an SD card and scripting in Python to facilitate image capture with a Raspberry Pi camera module. By the culmination of the spring semester, I had a fully functional prototype that enabled outdoor shooting.

During the subsequent summer term, my primary focus revolved around mastering the art of 3D printing to create a more polished camera body. I used Fusion 360 to create precise 3D models, which I materialized using a 3D printer. Upon the completion of the 3D printed prototype, I proceeded to construct a server that uploaded images directly to my dedicated website. Utilizing HTML, CSS, and Javascript, I built the website and incorporated the Greensock animation library.
projects.conclusion:
This project represents a deeply personal exploration that intertwines the realms of analog photography and software development. It has allowed me to challenge the limitations imposed by social media and algorithmic validation, encouraging a more authentic and meaningful engagement with photography. By fusing the tactile charm of analog photography with discreet digital integration, I have sought to bridge the gap between past and present, tradition and innovation.

Throughout this journey, I have ventured into uncharted territories, acquiring new skills in prototyping, 3D printing, and programming. The process has been one of growth, as I delved into the technical aspects of camera mechanics, expanded my knowledge of photography theory, and explored the psychology of sharing work on social media.

Moreover, this project has fostered a deeper understanding of the multifaceted nature of passions and the boundless possibilities that emerge when we break free from predefined boundaries. It serves as a testament to the power of embracing our diverse interests and uncovering new avenues for creative expression.

As I embark on the next phase of this project, I look forward to further refining my camera design, experimenting with different techniques, and continuing to challenge the conventions of digital photography. Ultimately, my goal is to inspire others to explore their own passions, break down barriers, and find unique ways to express themselves creatively in an ever-evolving digital landscape.

This project is a testament to the transformative potential of embracing our passions, blurring boundaries, and forging new paths of artistic exploration. It is a reminder that our journey of self-discovery and creative expression is an ongoing process, one that continues to unfold with each new endeavor.

projects.elevator_pitch: Beyond The Spectrum is an immersive, illustrative exhibition that uses illustrations, audio, and chalk footsteps as a way to pay homage to the significant African Americans and their contributions throughout history.
projects.description: Beyond The Spectrum is an immersive, illustrative experience that uses a projector, chalk footsteps, audio, and illustrations as a way to pay homage to the African American figures that paved the way artistically for myself and others! I wanted to create this experience because I did not want their stories to be swept under the rug and forgotten. I chose to include my Grandparents at the end of my thesis because they too have experienced a lot as it pertains to skin color, and how that was used as a divisive factor during the 1950s-1980s. I felt it was important to tell their story and to make sure that the audience heard their voices as well! During a time where the color of their skin meant a lot, each of these individuals I chose to showcase all had to push against a system that was trying to silence them and their artistic visions. Their ability to break through that wall, created an artistic explosion, and a movement that transcended past skin color. Their boldness now allows myself and others to freely express ourselves.
projects.background: Beyond the Spectrum was originally my Black History series from roughly a year ago but when coming into the IMA Program, I knew I wanted to see how far I could push this. I knew my grandparents' stories were important and I wanted to somehow tie them into my collection. Some artistic influences for myself when starting this series were artists like Faith Ringgold, Mickalene Thomas and Kehindey Wiley! Reading Maya Angelou’s “Won't Take Nothing From My Journey Now” and seeing all of the documents my grandfather had relating to his time during the Memphis City Sit In, was all I needed to know that this was the best route to navigate.
projects.user_scenario: This installation is meant to be presented in a dark room, the chalk footsteps lead the individuals to the exhibition. The illustrations are projected on a large scale in a dark room, and the users can go in, sit down, and watch!
projects.technical_system: My project consists of many parts that work cohesively together! The illustrations, the time-lapse drawing of my grandparents, the interview of my grandparents, the original soundtrack I made, the audio voices gathered, and the chalk footsteps.
projects.conclusion: I did learn a lot! For myself and others all I wanted to do was create something that was meaningful, and educational! I wanted to see for myself if I could make Black history interesting. Many forget that these events did not happen that long ago but sometimes the Black and White images we often see in history books can create distance and I felt that our culture is so artistically rich that using color was a no brainer. I also learned that after presenting my thesis at my alma mater Mt. Carmel High School on May 26th, 2023, the data revealed that only 41.2% of the students were knowledgeable about black history. To be located in the liberal and diverse city of San Diego, that result took me by surprise. If anything that lets me know that no matter how progressive we try to be, there is always more work to be done! :)
