projects.project_name: Self Talk to Self Confidence: Inspiring Women through Positive Affirmations
projects.elevator_pitch: Spread-positivity.com is a website that connects women and gives them access to community-generated positive affirmations to help build confidence, improve self-esteem, and build a support network. The site synthesizes current affirmation-building best practices and equips women with tools to craft more impactful and effective positive affirmations for use in their daily lives.
projects.description:
This project aims to create a community where women can share positive self-talk that helps them feel supported and empowered and teach them new phrases and ways of thinking that help them feel more connected and less alone.

Positive self-talk and manifesting have become buzz topics in recent years. The rise of lifestyle brands, self-help sites, and positive affirmation apps like Goop and I Am have helped bring self-care and affirmations into the mainstream. While these strive to empower women and provide them with tools for overcoming work stress and anxiety, the rise of the controversial “Girl Boss” culture has also left many feeling less confident and worse about themselves. I decided to do a deep dive into positive affirmations to see their efficacy as a confidence and self-esteem-boosting tool and how often women use them.

I started by sending a survey to dozens of women in my life. Reading through their responses, I found a common trend: women use their versions of affirmations and positive talk to combat negative feelings of imposter syndrome, stress, and anxiety. What was most shocking was how many of them struggled with imposter syndrome, how much their struggles resonated with me, and how their affirmations and self-talk made me feel more equipped to deal with the challenges in my life. 

As a starting point, I settled on creating a community-oriented website to connect women and allow them to share their insights and affirmations with other women. I was also intrigued by the idea that many of these women had created affirmations that could be even more impactful and effective with slight modifications to their wording and structure. This insight led to research into the semantics of affirmations, particularly phrasing, structuring, and repetition. I found a set of guidelines using wisdom from multiple sources within the psychology and self-help world and decided to make education a core component of my site. 

I began making wireframes and mockups of layouts, font choices, text, color schemes, and imagery to create an aesthetic and identity for my website. I sent these designs to friends and shared them with the IMA Low Res class to get their feedback and hone in on an approachable, user-friendly, and relaxing aesthetic. One friend recommended using music to craft a calming, mindful environment, so I found soothing soundtracks online to add as ambiance.

Overall, I am happy with the current look and feel of the site. My next steps for this project are: to create a functioning mockup of the site to allow for further user testing and improvement and to investigate the challenges of content moderation, community building, and community management.
projects.background:
The inspiration for this project is my self-confidence. I have always been a confident person, even as a young girl. I would do things authentically, sticking to myself and what I want to achieve. As I got older, I noticed that people applauded men for being ambitious and opinionated, while I was discouraged from being the same. I noticed that women always apologized for taking up space and voicing opinions, while men could be unapologetically themselves. As women, society expects us to be likable and digestible, to break ourselves down into little pieces to be more palatable. But our opinions should be swallowed whole - not in bite-sized chunks. I wanted to find a way to combat the notion that women need to bubblewrap their thoughts and ideas and help them be more themselves - unapologetically themselves.

I began by conducting primary research by sending a survey to women in my life to see if and how they were using positive affirmations to deal with the stresses and struggles that came up in their daily lives. To my surprise, most of the women who participated in my survey used some form of positive affirmation or self-talk to combat negative thoughts and self-talk, particularly feelings of imposter syndrome, anxiety, and work-related stress. Even more interesting was that few had conceptually heard of positive affirmations though they were already using positive affirmation-esque phrases almost daily. Another insight from the survey was the startling variation in the phrasing and structure of their positive self-talk. Some opted for longer, more complex sentences, while others employed shorter phrases that they would repeat frequently throughout their day.

These insights led to a deep dive into the current research and best practices for crafting and using positive affirmations. Studies have shown positive affirmations can "lead to increases in self-esteem, eudaimonic well-being, and positive attitudes toward oneself" (Arquiza). Effective self-talk is about "identifying, in really concrete ways, the kinds of things about you that you really value" (Chiu). Affirmations "require regular practice" (Moore) and "regular repetition" (Raypole). Essentially, for affirmations to be effective, they should use the present tense   (Moore), focus on core values and self-beliefs (Cohen & Sherman), employ action-oriented language (Steele), and be specific to a particular challenge or stressor (Steele). This research formed the basis for my site's guidelines for posting an affirmation to ensure that visitors can create useful and meaningful phrases that maximize the likelihood of positive outcomes.

I decided to use a website as the form for this project since websites are widely accessible globally and are not limited to specific platforms or operating systems in the way apps are. While I think there is potential to expand into the app space, wireframing a website felt like a more attainable goal given the time constraints of the Thesis process. 

My next steps in the research process are to investigate the current tools that exist for moderating user-submitted content as well as the challenges that can arise from giving visitors the option to post content anonymously.
projects.technical_system:
This project is a community oriented website for women to submit their personal experiences and affirmations to, as well as read about the affirmations and experiences of other women like them. In its current iteration, it features two technical components.

The first is a mockup of a community-oriented website built around connecting women and allowing them to craft and share positive affirmations they use. I employed modern, minimalist design aesthetics to give the site a clean and calming vibe. Having the text in the center of the page draws the visitor's focus to the core aspect of the website: user-generated positive affirmations. Based on user testing and feedback, I added the loading bar on the bottom of the page to inform the visitor that the currently displayed text is about to be changed. The simple "save" button allows visitors to favorite affirmations, and the "submit affirmation" button lets them add content to the site. The arrows allow visitors to view positive affirmations they have seen or skip a positive affirmation if it doesn't resonate with them. 

The second technical component of the project is the guide for creating effective affirmations. This element draws on current research and best practices for building positive affirmations to provide visitors with the semantic structure to create effective affirmations. I condensed the insights of several researchers and psychologists in the field into four easy-to-follow guidelines: be specific, focus on "I" statements, use present tense, and use active language.
projects.conclusion:
I learned so much from this experience about myself, my friends, and the struggles of women moving through the world around me. I have strengthened my connection to people within my circle, learned dozens of new affirmations that have helped me in my everyday life, and connected women going through similar struggles to each other to build a wider community. For example, I have a couple of women in my life dealing with medical issues, and I connected them through this project. I was excited to hear that they stayed in touch and have been able to lean on and support one another! 

I started this project with a simple goal: to investigate the prevalence and efficacy of positive affirmations. Through initial surveys, I found that many women use positive affirmations to combat negative thoughts and self-talk. These surveys also opened up deeper conversations with the women involved, inspiring me to consider building a platform where women could share and connect. 

As I researched deeper into affirmations and how they work, I discovered that there are a simple set of important recommendations to make an effective affirmation. Most women surveyed did not employ these guidelines in the positive self-talk they were creating. This insight led me to include an educational element in this project. I also received user feedback when testing affirmation submission wireframes that encouraged me to display simple best practices to follow when writing affirmations during the affirmation submission process. I also refined the wording and example phrases to align with the current research and professional suggestions around positive affirmation generation.

I started this project with a simple, rudimentary set of wireframe designs and refined and elevated the aesthetic based on user feedback and testing. Many of my initial wireframes were too complex or unintuitive. My test users preferred the clean, minimalist aesthetics they found in self-help apps that they were using on their phones. I ultimately decided to remove unnecessary site elements to place a greater emphasis on the affirmations themselves (which appear in the center of the page). The current aesthetic is calming yet lively and encourages engagement and sharing. User testers noted that the experience of a new affirmation replacing an old one was jarring, so I implemented a loading bar at the bottom of the site to give them a sense of when the text would disappear.

This project was an illuminating experience for me. It strengthened my connection to friends and mentors and allowed me to push my comfort zone and attempt to design a website - something I had never tried before. It also equipped me with tools and research to create more impactful affirmations.

projects.elevator_pitch: An app that helps reduce doom scrolling using goal setting and positive reinforcement to refocus wasted online time into offline fun.
projects.description:
In the digital age, people fall into the trap of wasting excessive time online, leading to unhappiness and discontentment. The allure of social media, streaming platforms, and endless sources of entertainment has blurred the line between intentional and habitual internet use, resulting in a neglect of offline experiences and a negative impact on well-being.

Endless scrolling through social media feeds, binge-watching TV shows, and succumbing to clickbait articles have become commonplace time sinks. Doom scrolling and time wasted surfing the web increase feelings of loneliness, depression, and anxiety. The constant exposure to carefully curated online personas can trigger a sense of inadequacy and negatively impact self-esteem. 

The core of this project is to reframe our relationship with time and prioritize meaningful offline experiences and intentional online use. It aims to inspire individuals to reclaim their time by setting boundaries and goals for screen time and offering tools to help spend time doing offline activities that promote human connection, hobby building and growth, and physical activity. Actively allocating time to hobbies, outdoor pursuits, and face-to-face interactions creates a more fulfilling and balanced life.

By embracing a mindful approach to time management and shifting the focus from the virtual world to the real world, this project empowers individuals to live fuller lives offline, nurturing their mental, emotional, and physical well-being. Through these efforts, people can rediscover the joys of genuine human connection and enrich their lives beyond the confines of the digital realm.
projects.background:
The background of this project is rooted in my personal struggle with wasting time on the internet. Losing track of time on the internet is an everyday occurrence – we all do it. I can’t count how many times I’ve looked over at the clock to see that it’s 2am, and I wasted hours of my night scrolling through the web. It almost never feels like time spent, just time wasted. I will often catch myself filling hours of the day with Netflix or doom scrolling, and thinking, why am I doing this?

As I dug deeper into my research, a worrying trend emerged. Individuals are feeling increasingly unhappy despite the lure of online distractions and the supposed “connection” promised by social media apps and digital platforms. In my own life, friends noted that they want to spend more time off of their phones, but felt like they would be missing out if they were ever offline.

While there are several existing technologies for tracking digital habits, most are centered around providing data and aiding in restricting app use. This project goes a step further by providing educational tools, happiness check-ins, goal setting for offline time use, and an emphasis on building a full life outside of the lures of digital space.

The core of my research centered around the best tools and tactics for creating lasting change for individuals. A common trend of gamification through a combination of goal setting and positive reinforcement emerged, so I used that as the central theme for this time saving app.
projects.technical_system: In its current iteration, this project exists as an app mockup. Given the time constraints of Thesis and the complexities of app development and design, this approach made the most sense. The core of the app is to provide an uplifting, goals-oriented approach with positive reinforcement. This is done through the app setup in the form of a questionnaire aimed at having the user set personal goals as well as apps to track and manage, and in the general design of the app which highlights time savings - as a positive reinforcement - as well as displaying the time spent on offline activities.
projects.conclusion:
This project has undergone several iterations and pivots based on user testing and feedback. Initially, the app design and focus was on a hybrid model of punishment and positive reinforcement. This was ultimately a sub-optimal approach since users will simply delete or stop using an app that makes them feel bad about themselves. Diving further into the research as well, punishment has been shown to be an ineffective tool in changing behavior long term which is a core goal of the project and app itself. 

Ultimately, the model that landed best both with users and existing research is a hybrid goal-setting and positive reinforcement model. Users set goals based on their desired behavior changes (for example: Save 30 minutes per week), and the app provides helpful tips and tools for achieving those goals. As goals are achieved, the app provides positive reinforcement through notifications and in app messaging to encourage further time saving.

The design of the app itself has likewise undergone several changes and improvements. The color scheme and vibe are heavily influenced by health and meditation apps as well as traditional time management apps. The core difference is that most time management apps are focused on improving productivity not happiness. The goal of this app is to reframe our intentionality around digital use not improve work output or other productivity oriented goals.

projects.elevator_pitch: Perceptible Radio Waves is an exploration into a ubiquitous, yet normally imperceptible phenomena that drives modern telecommunication. This is a device that guides an audience through contemplation of what radio waves are, how they have become nearly inescapable in our modern society, and allows space to reflect how this could be effecting our lives.
projects.description:
Society has seen a drastic shift in how humans communicate since the advent of wireless telecommunications. Many of these technologies, such as cellular data and WiFi, use radio waves to transmit data through the air. These imperceptible waves are ubiquitous in our lives, yet how often do we consider the physical material that our modern wireless world is built upon?

Perceptible Radio Waves is an exploratory project that aims to break down the abstractions of telecommunications to a physical representation of the phenomenon that they are built upon, namely radio waves. The ultimate goal is to figure out if engaging with radio waves through artistic practice can allow individuals to gain a deeper, more intuitive understanding of what radio waves are.

The main output of the project is a Perceptible Radio Device that guides an audience in observation of the physical space around them. Through guided audio, the audience is encouraged to consider that which they can perceive in the air through their senses, such as the temperature, the and quality of the light. They are then asked to compare that experience with the imperceptible activity that is also occurring in their space, specifically focusing on the radio waves oscillating all around them.
In addition to the guided audio, the device is also observing FM radio signals in real-time, and translates those signals into changing light patterns, revealing the invisible activity occurring in the air.
projects.background:
My process during this project was centered around creating and physical immersion. I hoped that by creating with my hands, and physically putting myself into situations where I could contemplate radio waves, I could gain knowledge physically somehow. 
- I created a crystal radio by using conductive wire, and a germanium diode.
- I used a technique where I made sculptural pieces based on my reading of Understanding Radio Waves by Peter Bubb:
    - “crystal thing with wires” explores my learning that a diode is a very thinly sliced crystal that vibrates at a particular frequency.
    - “antenna sculpture” is made up of twinkle lights attached to the antenna of an old radio to demonstrate that antennas work by passing an alternating current throughout the antenna to generate electric and magnetic fields.
- My favorite part of the process was my site visit to the US National Radio Quiet Zone, which is an area of land where the government limits radio transmission, to allow radio telescopes at the Greenbank Observatory to observe naturally occurring, faint radio waves from outer space. There is a health condition called electromagnetic hypersensitivity, and those who have it report negative side effects from exposure to electromagnetic radiation like wifi and cell data. Some of these people claim that moving to the Quiet Zone helps, and since my goal is to intuitively understand radio waves, I visited the Quiet Zone to see if I observed a physical difference while I was there. Though I didn’t observe any notable, immediate physical sensations, the lack of internet and cell service did impact how I went about my life while I was there. For a longer duration, I would imagine that the lack of radio waves would have impacted my life significantly.  While in the Quiet Zone, I also captured data at the Greenbank Observatory with my software-defined radio dongle. This was used in creating visual output with the Perceptible Radio Device representing a lack of radio activity.
projects.technical_system:
The Perceptible Radio Waves device is comprised of a Raspberry Pi running a Python application, a software-defined radio dongle, and neopixel lights. The Python application has three main components:
- A radio-reader component that reads in data from a software-defined radio dongle, and puts it onto a shared queue. This component uses the pyrtlsdr package.
- A feedbacker component that takes raw radio sample data and transforms it into light patterns using the neopixels lights.This component uses the adafruit-circuitpython-neopixel package.
- An audio-guider that is responsible for playing the different audio tracks via Python’s playsound package.

There is also an orchestrator component that is responsible for managing passing data from the shared queue to the different components.
projects.conclusion:
In 2017 I learned about Hedy Lamarr and her patent for the Secret Communication System that she co-created with composer George Antheil in 1942. Since then I’ve had a strong desire to know what Lamarr knew. At the time, I read about electricity, the electromagnetic spectrum, radio waves and their application. I learned about Lamarr’s life, and her inventions, yet still craved a deeper understanding of the materiality of radio waves. I put this quest down for several years, and when given an opportunity to do a deep dive into a topic for thesis, I immediately knew that I wanted to revisit radio waves. The fundamental query that drove my work was if it was possible to understand typically imperceptible waves more deeply and intuitively, if I shifted my approach from purely scientific to using an artistic lens, with specific intention on embodied senses. 

My initial plan was to recreate science experiments with the hopes of learning about the electromagnetic spectrum at a very basic level before adding abstractions on top of the fundamental concepts; abstractions like telecommunications. However, as I began with my first experiment of creating a crystal radio based on a video tutorial, I realized that though this tutorial was very hands-on, I still didn’t understand the basic materiality of radio waves. Also, the crystal that I created did not work, and I had very little understanding at the time to figure out how to troubleshoot the issues I was facing. At this point, I reflected and realized that I again was trying to understand this abstract topic through scientific exploration instead of using a the creation-based research approach that I had set out to use.

I then began working with a new technique where I made sculptural pieces based on my reading of Understanding Radio Waves by Peter Bubb. The two pieces that I created during this phase of creation were “crystal thing with wires” in which I explored my new knowledge that diodes are very thinly sliced crystals that vibrate at a particular frequency, and “antenna sculpture” which represented the mechanics of how alternating current travels through an antenna to generate electric and magnetic fields.

A highlight of the research process was a visit to the Greenbank Observatory in the US National Radio Quiet Zone. The Quiet Zone is an area of land where the amount of radio transmission is greatly limited, so that the Greenbank Observatory can observe faint, naturally occurring radio waves from outer space. My intentions with this visit wer to see if an absence of radio waves would be perceptible, and to collect some radio signal data with my software-defined radio dongle. Though I didn’t observe a notable different physically, the lack of WiFi and cell service did force a different way of communicating, and I wonder if over a longer period of time this may impact one’s life significantly.


The visit to the Greenbank Observatory’s science exhibition also proved to be important part of my process. Having the opportunity to compare exhibits that interactively demonstrated scientific phenomenon with those that relied on text alone solidified my desire to explore radio waves with an artistic lens. It fortified my thought that I want to create a physical piece that helps make radio waves more perceiptible. I also realized that though creating educational tools for kids isn’t necessarily the core driving force of this work, it is a good benchmark. If I’m able to create something that can make kids feel and understand something invisible, like radio waves, hopefully, I’ll also have gotten that same understanding myself. Going forward with this project, this will be a touchstone that I hope to revisit.


I believe that my research was successful in that I do have a deep understanding of radio waves than when I started, but I believe that my work is not yet complete.


Next Steps:
The existing iteration of the device is stationary, and translates radio waves signals into light patterns. The initial concept of the device was a mobile device that users could plug headphones into, and walk around their space observing changes in radio signals. The original concept also included haptic and audio feedback, to not only further the embodiment of radio waves, but also to allow for the device to be accessible to a wider audience.

In the future, I am planning to incorporate in this work include an exploration of spirituality, which is another field where humans are asked to believe in that which they cannot see. Additionally, I am hoping to include further research into epistemology to continue to tease at the question: how can I intuitively know radio waves?

projects.elevator_pitch: This is an interactive art installation about climate change and rising sea levels. It creates a rain effect through the melting of ice blocks, gradually submerging a city located at the bottom of the installation.
projects.description: The theme of my thesis project is global climate change and rising sea levels, focusing on the gradual loss of habitable land for humans. I have created a series of artworks depicting a story where the sea engulfs the last piece of land on Earth, forcing humanity to live in the ocean. In my research, I have extensively studied the effects of climate change leading to rising sea levels, and I have become aware of the severity of environmental destruction. However, over the past three years, the pandemic has led to reduced human travel, slowed trade and production, resulting in some positive trends in environmental data. While the reality of environmental damage cannot be completely reversed, I believe that if everyone pays attention and takes appropriate measures, improvements can be made. That's why I created this interactive art installation, which I hope to showcase in a park during the summer in New York. Through a visually compelling way, I aim to remind people to cherish the environment—it's not too late to act.
projects.background:
The background of my thesis involves extensive research and exploration in various areas, their are climate change, submerged cities, the impact of climate change on marine flora and fauna, sea-level expansion, predictions of future sea-level rise, climate improvement strategies, the redemption of marine flora and fauna, and the impact of visual installation art on viewers. The direct cause of sea-level rise is the melting of polar ice caps, so I decided to incorporate ice elements into my thesis. As a result, I researched various artworks related to ice, most of which involved directly melting ice blocks to visually convey the sensation of something large diminishing in size, directly impacting the audience's senses. Among many works, a piece from an Australian artist, Vicki Van Hout particularly caught my interest. It was a performance installation where the artist danced on a suspended three-ton ice block until it melted. Although it lacked interactive content, it genuinely raised my deep concerns about sea-level rise and the loss of land for humanity, invisibly motivating me to take action for environmental protection.
Many years ago, I had the opportunity to collaborate with WWF, China, for the past few years they have focused on water resource conservation. This collaboration reaffirmed my understanding of their focus and helped me solidify the framework for designing this project. Utilizing the limited resources available to me, I created a mini version of the installation and tested it with different individuals, aiming to identify any issues and find effective solutions during the testing phase. Indeed, various imperfections arose during the real-world testing process, but I have taken the most effective measures to address them thus far.
Overall, my research and exploration have deepened my understanding of environmental destruction, and now I have a clearer understanding that everyone's individual efforts can contribute to helping our environment. This has further strengthened my conviction that this topic is necessary for human survival. Through interactions with climate experts and artists, I have questioned my previous belief that science and art are unrelated, realizing that every artwork is the accumulation of extensive research, exploration, and rigorous testing.
projects.user_scenario: My project is an interactive installation. Audiences approach, temperatures rise, ice melts, and the melted water into the rain generator, gradually submerging the city in simulated rainfall. It is as if the audiences become the rain creators who can control the rain, with the water ultimately engulfing the city. Just like the current climate change and rising sea levels, human greed exacerbates the speed of sea level rise.
projects.technical_system:
My project is an interactive installation consisting of three parts: a bottom container with a city landscape, a rainmaker in the middle, and a top container with ice blocks. Users can interact with the installation within the exhibition area. The design of the installation aims to raise awareness about climate change and rising sea levels through visual effects and interactive experiences.
During the initial construction phase, I used Arduino development boards and sensors to implement the interactive features of the installation. I wrote Arduino code to control the sensor feedback and the behavior of the installation. Throughout the fabrication process, I encountered some issues and sought technical advice and guidance from David. After our discussions, I decided to change the interaction method. Considering the installation going to display in public open spaces, considering public safety, I have designed the current version of the project as a physical installation that fully complies with public safety standards.
The materials used in the project include acrylic containers, cotton, purification cotton pads, sand, and resin city landmarks, and ice cube. I also utilized various hand tools and electronic tools to fabricate and assemble the different parts of the installation.
Users can access my project in public exhibition spaces, art galleries, or parks. I plan to showcase the installation in a park during the summer in New York and invite people to come close, interact with it, and experience it.
projects.conclusion:
Throughout the research, exploration, development, material customization, and testing process of the entire project, I have learned the importance of researching and exploring new methods, as well as realizing the diversity of contemporary art. Through communication with various material suppliers, I discovered the fast pace of material innovation and the wide variety of materials available in the market, which provides me with more presentation options for my future art design. However, due to practical constraints and time limitations, I had to make choices in the creative and presentation processes.
In the project, I discovered that interactive art originates through the small details of life, and interaction is not limited to technological methods alone. Traditional physical methods can also achieve excellent interactive effects. I realized that the interactivity of art can be realized through the interaction between people and objects, the interaction between the audience and the exhibition area, and the interaction among the audience themselves. This kind of interaction can evoke the audience's emotions and thoughts, and stimulate their attention to issues such as climate change and rising sea levels.
Through user testing and feedback from the audience, I further improved the design and functionality of the project. These tests helped me understand the audience's experience of interacting with the installation and their perception of the visual effects. I made adjustments and optimizations based on the feedback. At the same time, these tests also made me realize the power of art, as it can resonate with the audience and inspire them to take action on environmental issues.
Overall, through this project, I have learned how to combine art with environmental issues to create meaningful works and generate audience attention and action. I deeply understand the importance of art in conveying information, inspiring thinking, and promoting social change. I will continue to explore and challenge myself to create more art pieces related to environmental and social issues.

projects.elevator_pitch: The starry sky that breathes
projects.description: When I stand under the starry sky, I feel its tranquility and vastness, its loneliness and charm. I try to integrate these complex emotions into my works of art, hoping to arouse the viewer's deep thinking about the universe and self-existence. Feel the poetry and brilliance of those distant stars, fly under the wings of art, transcend the constraints of reality, and welcome the infinite possibilities of the universe. The starry sky always brings the source of fantasy to people from ancient times to the present. It is an important source of inspiration for human beings. It is becoming more and more difficult to get in touch with the starry sky in the current urban life. I hope that I can make a starry sky by myself, a breathing starry sky, to hug you.
projects.background: Flying Apsaras is an art that combines romanticism and realism. It comes from Buddhist culture and is rooted in the fertile soil of Chinese traditional culture, with a strong romanticism. Flying into the sky is not only a dream that humans have had since ancient times, it is reflected in many myths and stories, and it is also a fantasy that almost every child had in childhood. When I was a kid sitting on the back of my mother's bike, I would stretch out my hands and imagine myself flying. As I grew up, I gradually came into contact with roller coasters, hot air balloons, airplanes, glider, etc. The feeling of being close to the sky always makes me intoxicated. In my flying experience again and again, I felt the joy that the gods worshiped by the ancestors left the earth, lived in the sky, and could come and go freely. This romantic cultural concept is deeply imprinted in my heart. In my eyes, these works of art that explore the sky and the universe perfectly fit the ideal of flying into the sky in the national cultural concept, and become the carrier of this romantic cultural concept, constantly encouraging and motivating people to strive for it. Flying Apsaras symbolizes the pursuit of human beings yearning for freedom, daring to explore, transcending nature, and getting rid of the constraints of space. It is a positive aesthetic tone.

projects.elevator_pitch: Using different storytelling methods in one interactive film to create empathy and understanding between characters and the audience.
projects.description:
Last Night Memory is an interactive film that contains traditional film screening, AR, and VR experiences. The project uses three different methods of storytelling to show one story in three views: third-person (film), first-person(AR), and the character's mental world(VR). 

The story is about a murder in a family, and is told in a way of "flashback memory". Memory tends to be blurry and ambiguous, so it comes in fragments. The truth appears when all fragments are connected.
projects.background: "After you've walked where a character has walked, seen what they've seen, then you look at their face again, do you feel different about them?" This is the main question of my thesis project. As a filmmaker, I always explore new methods of storytelling in order to build a deeper empathy and understanding between the audience and characters, which is far beyond telling the story plot. I want my audience to dive into the character by switching the third-person view to a first-person view, and eventually see the mental world of the character. I've done research on how gaming, AR, and VR help build an interactive storytelling experience, and how they make audience "become" the characters.
projects.user_scenario: The audience will watch the film (3min) first from the TY screen to get the main plot, and then they will use AR to check the "space" with an Ipad to have empathy with the character. Finally, they will wear the VR headset to dive into the character's mental world to build an understanding.

The project creates an immersive and interactive storytelling experience.

projects.elevator_pitch: The exploration of the connection between digital media and physical media and how that connection can educate a user about something new, while providing a comforting environment
projects.description: My project entails the exploring the connection between physical media and digital media and how this connection can create an immersive experience for the user that teaches them about something new through a comforting environment. The topic I want to teach about is salsa dancing/music since it's such a personal space for me and the comforting environment I am creating is through a cozy coffee shop. I hope that this experience can encourage the user to find community around them or even appreciate whatever other community they are part of.
projects.background:
The background of my project comes from my experience as a salsa dancer. For 7 years. I have been performing and teaching salsa dancing and have been learning the culture of salsa music as a result. Throughout my life, I’ve moved around a lot and have changed a lot of aspects of my life, however, salsa dancing and music has stayed constant throughout.  More recently, I have been working as a barista for almost six months, and have always been interested in coffee shops and why we as human beings gravitate towards them, especially as I’ve found myself always doing so. I see coffeeshops as the perfect setting for spending downtime with each other.In addition to my personal background behind this project, I have also conducted some research on the correlation between comfort and coffee shops such as: 

Lastly, due to the accessibility my coffee shop position provides, I have interviewed 4 of our regular customers asking them questions such as: “How long have you been coming to this coffee shop?”, “Why do you like coming here everyday?”, “What is it about this coffee shop that you feel allows you to come here and socialize or work?” as a way to gain personal understanding into their source of comfort. Their responses were documented, and implemented throughout the project to create a sense of empathy and continued immersiveness for the user.
projects.technical_system:
My project will be presented in a spinal cord book format which will allow for a top down journey or a one way path that the user can go through step by step. The user will be prompted to scan various QR codes that will take them back and forth from the website I created back to the book. The experience will heavily rely on both the book and the website and the user will not be able to move forward without each other. My reasoning for this is because this thesis is about the exploration of physical and digital media and the connection between them. Therefore I feel it’s important I reinforce that connection by making these two mediums dependent on each other. I personally believe that the experience is not possible without either the digital format or physical one. 
For more detailed information, I used Wix as the website builder, and Canva for the design of the book pages that contain the content and information.

What is that feeling?

Haptic Memory is an immersive experience that connects audio narratives with haptic reactions to bring awareness to our memories' mind/body connection and greater impact on our lives over time.
Sometimes, those memories are so traumatic that we disassociate. What is it like to reintroduce that memory and notice your body's hidden protective behaviors?

Other times, those memories are so sweet they become the pinnacle of how we measure our happiness. Even if the people associated are no longer relevant in our lives, why do our bodies hold on to the feeling? 
 
The prototype of Haptic Memory investigates our common psychosomatic sensations, brought to life through Arduino and wireless computation rigged into a wearable vest. The sensations aim to authentically express the depth of these stories where words fall short. 

No matter the narrator's experience, similar sensations reoccurred in the process of haptic scoring: racing heart, ringing in the ears, change in temperature, and butterflies in the stomach -- leading to expansive questions about the universal processes of internalizing past experiences beyond the imagination.  

Anonymous participants for this project graciously provided their personal narratives to be experienced and scored with their matching sensations.
projects.background:
In its simplest form think about how when you reflect on an embarrassing moment from your past, and how you feel the cringe in your body when you recall the experience. 
While that memory may be many years behind you, you still have the visceral reaction in your body from the experience today. What is that feeling? 

I knew I wanted to focus on storytelling and tie the thread of my IMA projects circled around kinship, memory, and shared experience into a culminating project.  

I decided I wanted to use some kind of haptic device to allow users to put on an experience, and narrowed down to the idea of replicating memories through storytelling. 

This ultimately breaking my project into two parts -
Part 1. Storytelling of memories 
Part 2. Creating a corresponding wearable to score the stories with.

I broke my research into 4 sections; Storytelling, Embodiment, Mental Health, and Technical Feasibility & Considerations. A list of my sources and research materials are listed in the references section.
projects.user_scenario:
In the installation's final form, visitors will be welcomed into a private space and invited to experience these narratives not only in sound via headphones but also through tactical feeling through a haptic wearable, allowing them to step into someone’s past experience and “put on” their memory for themselves. The work is meant to be experienced privately, in the absence of private space, an eye mask can be worn to help remove surrounding distractions.

For those unable to experience the vest in person, a virtual experience is also available at www.hapticmemory.info

projects.conclusion:
Spring Semester:
I tested the project concept in our Spring “Show-A-Thing” sessions held virtually over Zoom. In the absence of narratives and a prototype leveraging an excerpt of a  pre-recorded story from The Moth Radio Hour, titled The Weight of a Ring. I had a brief run-through of the physical reactions I was interested in replicating and showed the participants how to mimic heat, racing heartbeat, and tightening chest with their hands. Before we started, I asked participants to turn off their cameras for privacy. As the story played, I prompted the participants with slides that cued when to simulate physical reaction. This session helped me create more clarity in the storytelling of the topic/concept and emotionally-induced reactions to omit and dive deeper into. This mode of concept testing was conceived by Sarah Rothberg. In my anxiety of how to test something that didnt yet exist, her clever resourcefulness and support lead to the ability to test my concept with an invisible prototype. This method has resurfaced in the summer as a mode of showing my project virtually for folks in Shanghai and beyond. 

Once the concept was solidified, I met with David Rios and Daniel Ryan Johnston to discuss materials, feasibility, and technical specifics to create the physical computing elements, such as the haptic vest and sound synching for the experience and helping me align on feasible scope.

Before starting the process of collecting narratives from participants, I wanted to be sure I was taking the necessary care ad respect with participants' stories, so in co-creation with my thesis mentor Cy X, we were able to review and craft content for a consent form, a questionnaire, and outline Before/During/After Care strategies for participation. This protocol development taught me trauma-informed strategies and how to prepare the best headspace for tough conversations with myself and the participant. I created an “open call” through my social media accounts to recruit participants to share memories. After discussing the project intent with folks who responded, I narrowed in on two narrators, and shared a consent form and questionnaire to get initial data on the stories they planned to share such as their sentiment toward the experience, where they feel the experience in their body when think about the memory, and any other notes needed to aid in their comfort for sharing these personal stories. Upon reviewing the documentation, I was especially interested in the fact that while their narratives resided on opposite ends of the emotional spectrum; the sensations described were similar such as: ringing in the ears, change in temperature, and racing heart. 



Summer Session:
The focus of the Summer session was the production and refinement of the experience. Before scheduling sessions with the two anonymous narrators, I created a one-sheeter for them each to review which provided an overview of the processes Cy X and I collaborated on to prep for their recording session. 

Before starting our recording sessions, we reviewed these processes together, taking deep breaths, and setting the space for safety and good intention. After the narrators recorded their experiences, I checked in on how they felt recalling their stories and made notations of what and where they physically felt their emotions in the retelling process to be scored in the vest. While the audio scoring sets the scene and ambiance of the memory.

With my recordings collected, I edited down the stories to fit into the experience, as well as scoring the audio with sounds to support the memory and the haptic sensations. 

For example, such as ringing in the ears and the sound of a pulsing heart help underscore the sensations in the vest. While muffled sounds of a restaurant, the DC metro, and a college party help enhance the understanding of where these impactful experiences took place. It’s a balance of past and present to tie together the larger composition. Once these audio pieces were complete, I leveraged Apple Music to house the audio and created a title graphic for the playlist.

The biggest challenge and learning experiences from the making of this project was within the physical computing of the vest. I bought a few different vests to test the best material that allowed the sensations to pass through, as well as the ideal construction for higind and fastening the components. Researching materials, finding different source code and tutorials to piece together into my circuits, and using SO much wire and zip ties to best layout the technical specs within the wearable vest. I learned so much, and have to send a special thank you to the following folks for supporting my production process:

David Rios, for introducing me to Arduino, circuit building, and physical computing during our introductory Interface Lab course in the Summer ‘22 session. It was due to this experience that I knew I wanted to revisit this mode of production for Thesis, and I am very thankful for the insight and support he provided throughout this process and making this project possible.

Daniel Ryan Johnston, for being an amazing wealth of knowledge for tutorials, materials, and source code. I would not know what  LilyPad, Loomia, or Conductive Thread was without your openness and generosity.  Your encouragement and support made me feel like anything was possible, and your overall warmth and big hug when we finally met in person was a much needed push after a few all night sessions in the Fab Lab, wiring and re-wiring the vest to its final prototype configuration.

Leah Buechley, Kate Hartman, & Madeline Maxey, this project would literally not exist without you. Not only are you inspiring, badass female e-textile engineers, but your willingness to share your knowledge through your components, tutorials, and writings was invaluable to providing a tangible roadmap forward to my Thesis production process. An especially major shout out to Kate Hartman for letting me borrow your LilyPad USB after I broke mine just days before Thesis submission. In a true SOS moment, you truly saved the day and I am forever grateful for your kindness.

Last but not least, thank you to Allison Parrish, Patrick C. Warren, Ruta Kruliauskaite, and Davis Luceriaga, for helping me brainstorm the biggest conundrum of how to best convey the “haptic” nature of this work without being physically present for the Shanghai Thesis Show. Your production support allowed the truest experience possible to shine through in virtual form.

projects.elevator_pitch: Interactive experience to quietly observe the arrangement of groups as they rearrange themselves.
projects.description: PESCA is a network of nodes that communicate with each other to show different arrangements of individuals in groups as they occur. It is a manifestation of the quiet observation of a hopeful artist, curious about the nature of making choices in an world with an ever changing framework.
projects.background: The inspiration for this project was from observing the way individuals moved within groups.
projects.technical_system: Each node of PESCA utilizes an ESP32 microcontroller's Bluetooth capabilities to act as both a server and a client to broadcast and scan RSSI and unique ID to "find" each other, and send signals when any one node has wandered too far. The connections are entirely independent and do not rely on any central hub. Each node also uses a custom printed circuit board with embedded battery and charging unit to create a miniature node.
